etymologies: early 18th century: from modern Latin dicotyledones (plural), from di- ‘two’ + cotyledon (see cotyledon)

definitions: a flowering plant with an embryo that bears two cotyledons (seed leaves). Dicotyledons constitute the larger of the two great divisions of flowering plants, and typically have broad, stalked leaves with netlike veins (e.g., daisies, hawthorns, oaks).

notes.text: Class Dicotyledoneae (or -donae, -dones; sometimes Magnoliopsida), subdivision Angiospermae

shortDefinitions: flowering plant with embryo that bears two cotyledons
